Award.AwardTitle: IDBR: TYPE A Development of On-Chip Electrochemical Cross-Linking Mass Spectrometry for Probing Protein-Protein Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
An Award is made to Ohio University to develop an on-chip electrochemical cross-linking mass spectrometry which will be used to identify protein-protein interactions (PPIs) in vivo. The study of PPIs is very important to understand protein biological functions as the biological functions of almost all proteins are provided by specific, non-covalent interactions with other molecules. The identification of interacting partners and interaction sites of protein complexes or aggregates will shed light on the elucidation of biological process mechanisms. This instrumentation project will provide opportunities for students to be trained in interdisciplinary research involving analytical chemistry, biochemistry, and instrumentation. The proposed instrument for biological research will first be used for the study of UV-induced apoptotic signaling pathways. Following instrument construction and software training, many other biological research groups in structural and molecular biology at Ohio University will have access to the developed instrument. The instrument will also serve as a prototype instrument for commercialization, enabling dissemination to the biological research community. It is expected that the proposed research will benefit the research communities of structural biology, molecular biology, and drug discovery.

Cross-linking mass spectrometry (MS) has become a useful technique for mapping protein-protein interactions and elucidating protein networks in living cells. However, several experimental obstacles limit the usefulness of cross-linking MS, including difficulty in the identification of cross-linked peptides in the complex mixture, the complexity of the fragmentation patterns of cross-linked peptide ions and the inability to quantify cross-links. This project proposes a new approach using electrochemistry (EC)-assisted cross-linking MS for probing protein-protein interactions in vivo, based on an electrochemical cross-linking reagent, diselenide [succinimidyl propionate] (SSP). Following online digestion, the cross-linked protein complexes will undergo capillary electrolysis (CE) separation, online EC reduction and online MS detection. The EC reduction provides a novel way to quickly identify and quantify cross-links based on the reduction current (also on MS signal), significantly reducing time required for data analysis by more than one order of magnitude. The online EC reduction takes seconds, which is much faster than hours required in chemical reduction. Furthermore, EC reduction yields easily identifiable linear peptides, facilitating MS/MS identification of cross-link structures for pinpointing out the interaction sites in the protein complexes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under the support of this NSF IDBR (CHE-1455554) grant, many successes were obtained, including developments of new devices and methodologies for probing protein-protein interactions (also 3D structures) and chemical quantitation. Totally 24 original paper articles in peer-reviewed journals were published, in addition to 2 more review articles. Major research outcome are briefly summarized below.  

 

1. We developed a new electrochemical mass spectrometric approach for probing protein 3D structure in combination with isotope labeling. The isotope labeling also allows us to reveal protein conformational change using comparative cross-linking strategy (J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 2016, 27, 864-875).

 

2. We developed a new absolute quantification device using combined mass spectrometry and electrochemistry (J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 2019, 30, 685?693). Such an absolute quantitation approach is sensitive and does not need the use of standards or isotope-labeled compounds. 

 

3. We reported the development of LC/EC/MS apparatus using UPLC. In addition, we adopted liquid sample desorption electrospray ionization (DESI) as the interface to couple the electrochemical cell with a mass spectrometer. This is the first time to integrate the high separation power of UPLC with electrochemical mass spectrometry (Eur. J. Mass Spectrom. 2015, 21, 341?351).

 

4. We developed an online time-resolved mass spectrometric apparatus for measuring kinetics of enzymatic reactions (Anal. Chem., 2017, 89, 2338?2344).

 

5. We developed a new atmospheric pressure neutral reionization (APNR) mass spectrometry which can be used to detect neutral fragments from a precursor ion dissociation event for gaining increased information for chemical structural analysis (Chemical Science, 2017, 8, 6499-6507)

 

6. We used our liquid sample DESI-MS successfully captured reactive monophosphine ligated Palladium (0) intermediates (J. Am. Chem. Soc., 2015, 137, 14035-14038) as well as transient electrochemical reaction intermediates such as dimethylaniline radical cation and nitrenium cations (Angew. Chem. Int. Ed., 2015, 54, 11183 ?11185 and Chemical Science, 2016, 7, 329). We also investigated the mechanism of nucleophile-promoted gold redox catalysis using mass spectrometry (Chem. Sci., 2016, 7, 6190) and studied the mechanism of silver-free palladium-catalyzed sp3 and sp2 C−H alkynylation reaction by MS (Org. Lett. 2016, 18, 2970-2973).

 

7. We developed electrochemistry-assisted online mass spectrometric technology for the study of visible light-triggered photoredox reaction mechanism (J. Am. Chem. Soc., 2017, 139, 12259?12266). We also studied gold-catalyzed alkyne hydration reaction using mass spectrometry (MS) and discovered a key dual-gold reaction intermediate involved in the reaction (Chemistry - A European Journal, 2018, 24, 2144-2150)

 

8. We identified carbon monoxide, a neutral species that is lost during ionic dissociation of protonated amino acids using atmospheric pressure thermal dissociation mass spectrometry (APTD-MS) technique (J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 2018, 29, 2317?2326).

 

9. Nitric oxide (NO?) plays an important role in regulation of redox balance in keratinocytes post-UVB exposure. Since endothelial cells releases NO? for a prolonged time after exposing the cells to ultraviolet B light (UVB), we determined whether endothelial cells could have an effect on UVB-induced DNA damage and transformation of their adjacent keratinocytes using a 3D cell co-culturing system. Based on these results, we propose that endothelial cells promote inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) expression in adjacent keratinocytes. The increased NO? from iNOS suppresses the endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS) coupling in order to maintain a normal level of NO? in the cells. Upon UVB exposure, the uncoupled eNOS produces superoxide (O2?-) instead of NO?. Then O2?- reacts rapidly with NO?, which could be produced by iNOS, to form peroxynitrite (ONOO-) resulting in an increase of cyclobutane pyrimidine dimer (CPD) formation and cell transformation (Scheme 2) (Photochem. And Photobiol. 2019, 95: 338?344).


Last Modified: 06/10/2019
Modified by: Shiyong Wu
